prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is about a couple where the husband set up his office in their bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife. The wife suggested the basement, which is quieter. The husband prefers the bedroom for the view. The wife has to manage the kids and housework while he's on calls, and it's affecting her ability to do basic tasks. She told him she can't guarantee silence in the bedroom but would do so in the basement. He thinks she's the asshole for not being quiet, she thinks he's the asshole for not using the basement.

First, I need to assess who's wrong here. The key points are about mutual respect and consideration. The husband chose the bedroom despite the wife's suggestion. His job involves a lot of calls, which require silence, but he's in a space that's not ideal for that. The wife works from home too and has household responsibilities. By choosing the bedroom, he's creating a situation where she can't use the top floor normally, leading to her stress and inability to manage her tasks. 

Is the wife wrong for not keeping him undisturbed? Well, she's trying to manage the household. The husband's choice to work where there's more noise and less privacy impacts her daily life. The basement was available, so his decision to ignore her suggestion might be the main issue. The wife's responsibility is to manage the kids and housework, which is a lot already. If he were in the basement, maybe those tasks would be easier. But since he's in the bedroom, she can't do her things. 

So, the husband's choice is the root problem. The wife is trying to be reasonable by offering the basement but can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom. She's not the one at fault here. The answer should be B (No, the author is not in the wrong). The husband is the one who isn't considering the wife's needs by not using the basement as suggested.
